metadata.title: Mass-producible method for preparation of a carbon-coated graphite@plasma nano-silicon@carbon composite with enhanced performance as lithium ion battery anode

sections.text:
Carbon-coated core-shell structure artificial graphite@plasma nano-
silicon@carbon (AG@PNSi@C) composite, applying as lithium ion battery anode material, has been prepared via spray drying method. The plasma nano-silicon (˂ 100
nm), which contained amorphous silicon, was synthesized by radio frequency induction plasma system with the high temperatures processing capability and high quench rates. The artificial graphite in the composite acts as the core which supports the particle and provides electroconductivity, while PNSi attached on the surface of the core, enhances the specific capacity of the composite. The as prepared composite shows superior performance as anode in lithium-ion batteries, regarding to the initial Coulombic efficiency and cycle life. The initial Coulombic efficiency of AG@PNSi@C electrode is 81.0% with a discharge capacity of 553 mAh g-1 and a recharge capacity of 448 mAh g-1. During cycling, AG@PNSi@C exhibits excellent performance with a very low capacity fading that the discharge capacity maintains 498.2 mAh g-1 and 449.4 mAh g-1 after 250 cycles and 500 cycles. AG@PNSi@C also shows enhanced resistance against high current density. Besides the remarkable electrochemical performances, the facile and mass-producible synthesis process makes the AG@PNSi@C composite very promising for its application in lithium-ion batteries. Keywords: plasma nano-silicon, core-shell structure, spray drying, anode, lithium ion battery

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The requirement of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) increases greatly as people’s
living standard rising [1, 2]. Properties such as high energy density and long cycling life have become crucial elements for the development of LIBs [3]. High energy density, for LIBs, means that electrode materials can provide more capacity per unit
mass or per unit volume. The long cycling life, for LIBs, stands for the structural stability of cathode/anode active materials and their solid-fluid interface. Besides, safety, environmental friendliness and cost effectiveness also determine their applications. These properties and demands could be improved by the development of electrode materials [4, 5]. Recently, major advances in cathode have indeed been made by the development of Li2MnO3-based composite featuring theoretical capacity of 260 mAh g-1, of which all can be ascribed to its transition metal ions-based redox reactions [6, 7].
Besides cathode, a lot of efforts have been made to study anodes with high
capacity, such as alloy compounds (Si, Sn, Ge, or Al) and transition metal oxide (Fe, Co, Zn, or Mn) [8-11]. Alloy anodes with high theoretical specific capacity suffer from the huge volume expansion. Transition metal oxide anodes also exhibit an inevitable problem of the high lithium storage potential. In addition, their low electronic conductivity and structural change during conversion reaction result in poor rate and cycle performance. Compared with these anodes, silicon attracts great attention because of its very high theoretical specific capacity (~3579 mAh g-1 by forming Li15Si4 phase), which is about ten times larger than that of graphite (~372 mAh g-1 by forming LiC6 phase) [12-14]. In addition, low discharge/charge voltage plateau, reserve abundance, environmental friendliness and cost effectiveness of silicon entitle it as a very promising anode which can be applied in LIBs industry [15, 16]. Despite the advantages, there are still several problems to the application of silicon anode. The serious volume change (~300%) of Si during the lithiation/de-
lithiation process, causes the repeated formation of SEI film which further leads to poor cycle life and low Coulombic efficiency [17-19]. And pure Si owns a poor electronic conductivity which leads to poor cycling life and limits rate capability when conducting the battery under high current conditions [20-22].
Several strategies have been applied to address the above problems for Si based
anodes. Nano-sizing and carbon coating are effective ways to reduce the volume expansion and pulverization, and improve the poor conductivity of silicon [23-25]. Therefore, some silicon particles with special nano-structures, such as spherical, rod, sheet, and porous structures, present enhanced battery properties [26-28]. These special nanostructures, owning considerable specific surface area and void space, can buffer the volume changes and improve the lithium ion diffusion efficiency on the solid liquid interface [29-31]. In particular, several Si-C composites, such as Si-CNTs, Si-rGO, Si-hollow carbon spheres and Si-graphite composites, have been introduced for the application of Si [32-35]. These special Si-C composites can enhance the conductivity and also accommodate the huge volume changes during the lithiation/delithiation processes, improving the cycling performance and rate capability [36-39]. In brief, nano-structured Si combining with carbon matrix makes Si based composite an excellent anode candidate for LIBs. However, majority of the work aforementioned was based on the nano-techonology, which is not easy to scale up for mass production.
In this work, we prepared a mass-producible core-shell structured artificial
graphite@plasma nano-silicon@carbon (AG@PNSi@C) composite as anode for long
life span LIBs, via spray drying method. The core-shell structured composite contains artificial spherical graphite as the core, plasma nano-silicon (PNSi) and high temperature pitch as the shell. Spray drying is a facile way to achieve homogeneous micro-spherical particle materials and obtain mass production. The prepared AG@PNSi@C composite, wrapped by the conductivity carbon that can accommodate the volume change and reduce the polarization of Si, exhibits excellent electrochemical properties. The very low capacity fading after 500 discharge/charge cycles suggests the superior property of carbon-coated core-shell AG@PNSi@C as anode in LIBs.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preparation of artificial graphite@plasma nano-silicon@carbon
sections.text:
(AG@PNSi@C) composite
Plasma nano-silicon (PNSi) was prepared from commercial crystalline silicon
(CCSi) using radio frequency induction plasma system (TEKNANO-15; TDU15 Kw, Canada), as shown in Fig. 1a. Part of CCSi was changed into amorphous silicon. The AG@PNSi@C composite was then prepared using the above received silicon nanoparticle with artificial graphite and high temperature pitch through a spray drying method. The synthesis processes are shown in Fig. 1b. In a typical synthesis, 16.5 g artificial graphite (mean volume diameter: 16.3 µm; JiangXi ZiChen Technology Co., Ltd) and 0.5 g citric acid were dropped in 200 mL deionized water and stirred for 30 min to form a suspension. And 1.5 g Si nanoparticles were dispersed in 100 mL
deionized water via ultrasonic cell crusher under 400 W for 20 min. Then the two suspensions were mixed under vigorous stirring for 1 h to obtain slurry. The slurry went through a spray drying process to form AG@PNSi precursor under a centrifugal rotational speed of 35000 rpm with inlet temperature of 220 ºC and outlet temperature of 120 ºC. The precursor was calcined at 380 ºC for 4h under a nitrogen atmosphere to achieve AG@PNSi powders which were then dispersed in 200 mL deionized water. 2 g high temperature pitch was dissolved in 50 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) by stirring for 30 min and was mixed with the AG@PNSi suspension by vigorous stirring. Through spray drying for the second time, the mixture turns to be precursor of AG@PNSi@C. After heat treatment of 500 ºC for 3h following with 900 ºC for 3h under nitrogen atmosphere, the AG@PNSi@C composite is received.

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization
sections.text:
The phase information of the as-prepared samples was investigated using powder
X-ray diffractometry (XRD; PANalytical X’Pert PRO). The surface and crosssectional morphology of samples was observed by IM4000 Ion Milling System (Hitachi E-3500) and field emission electron microscopy (FSEM; ZEISS ULTRA 55). And transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM-2100HR) was applied to offer a vision of structure inside the particle. The carbon content in the AG@PNSi@C composite was detected using a micro-raman spectroscopy (Jobin Yvon LabRam HR800). To confirm the weight ratio of silicon in the composite, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, Nezsch Sta 409) was conducted.

sections.heading: 2.3 Electro-chemical measurement
sections.text:
The electrochemical performance of the prepared samples was investigated using
lithium half-cell system consisted of metal lithium anode, separator, electrolyte, and working electrode, based on CR2430 button cell assembled in an argon glove box. The electrolyte was comprised of 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in a mixed solution of EC/DEC/EMC (ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate/ethylene carbonate; GuangZhou Tinci Materials Technology Co., Ltd) by the volume ratio of 1: 1: 1. Working electrode was fabricated by coating and drying a cathode slurry, which is received by mixing 80 wt.% sample, 10 wt.% Super P and 10 wt.% carboxymethyl cellulose sodium salt (CMC: Aladdin LR)in proper N-Methyl Kelopyrro lidone (NMP: Aladdin AR), on a piece of copper foil. The average loading mass of electrode materials is approximately 1.06 mg cm-2 on the copper foil.
Cyclic voltammetry measurement of the assembled cell was conducted using
Solartron 1470E electrochemistry system within 0.01 and 2.5 V at a scan rate of 0.05 mV s-1. The cycling performance was tested using a voltage range from 0.01 V to 1.5 V at constant current of 100 mA g-1. The rate performance was investigated using the same voltage range at varied current densities from 100 to 1000 mA g-1.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The phase of the as-prepared AG@PNSi@C were determined by X-ray
diffraction method, and the patterns are shown in Fig. 2a. The main diffraction peaks
at 2θ =28.4°, 47.3°, 56.1°, 69.1° and 76.4° can be indexed to silicon (cubic phase: JCPDS# 00-027-1402) corresponding to (111), (220), (311), (400) and (311)lattice planes of the silicon crystal. And the peaks at 2θ =26.4°, 44.4°, 54.5° and 77.2° are indexed to graphite (crystal phase: JCPDS# 041-487) corresponding to (002), (101), (004) and (110) lattice planes [40, 41]. There is no obvious peak of SiC or SiO2 detected, indicating that Si and graphite stay stable during the calcining process under nitrogen atmosphere. The crystal degree for PNSi and milling commercial crystalline silicon (MSi) were also investigated using XRD method. Fig. 2b exhibits the XRD patterns of PNSi and MSi, in which the peaks of PNSi are broader and lower than those of MSi. As known, the lower degree of crystallinity for Si the lower volume expansion and better cycle performance during discharge/charge processes can be obtained compared with crystal Si [42, 43]. The results suggest that PNSi has lower crystal degree which would help for the performance as anode in LIBs.
Fig. 2c shows the Raman Spectrum of the AG@PNSi@C composite. The Raman
shift at 515 cm-1 presents an intense peak which could be related to silicon nanoparticle. The other two peaks at 1343 and 1579 cm-1 correspond to the D band and G band. The D band reflecting the signal of disordered carbon would be resulted from the pyrolysis of pitch. The G band corresponds to the sp2 hybridization structure of carbon [44, 45]. The high ratio for the intensity of G band to that of D band (~1.43) indicates that the carbon content in AG@PNSi@C has a certain degree of crystallinity because of the existence of artificial graphite, and the graphite carbon enhances
electrical conductivity of AG@PNSi@C composite.
Weight ratio of PNSi in the composite is an essential parameter that affects the
capacity and cycling ability. To get information of PNSi weight ratio, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, conducting in air atmosphere using a ramping rate of 10 °C min-1) curves for pure PNSi and AG@PNSi@C have been collected as the result shown in Fig. 2d. From TGA curves, when heated to 900 ºC in air atmosphere, the pitch carbon and graphite in the AG@PNSi@C composite were combusted and generated carbon dioxide gas leading to the main weight loss, while the PNSi in the composite was oxidized to SiO2 leading to the weight increase. According to the TGA of the pure PNSi particles, ~18.10% gain in mass was observed at 900 ºC [32, 46, 47]. The weight ratio of surplus material in the AG@PNSi@C composite was about 7.57% at 900 ºC in air. However, considering the small weight increase from the oxidation of PNSi between 25 and 900 ºC, the weight ratio of PNSi in the composite is calculated to be about 6.40 wt.% (7.57%/118.10%) from the TGA curves of pure PNSi and AG@PNSi@C.
SEM image shown in Fig. 3a shows that the particle size of PNSi ranges from 20
to 80 nm. As shown in Fig. 3b, the particle size of AG@PNSi@C prepared by spray drying method is uniformly distributed in the range from 11 to 20 µm. Fig. 3c and 3d show the core-shell structure of AG@PNSi@C in which the PNSi particles attach to the surface of graphite core. To further verify the core-shell structure of AG@PNSi@C, SEM image of the cross-sectional structure is presented in Fig. 3e and 3f. It can be observed clearly that PNSi is embedded in the graphite surface from
the cross-section of AG@PNSi@C. The structure of AG@PNSi@C was investigated by TEM in Fig. 3g. PNSi particles were wrapped in the pitch carbon. A few fuzzy diffraction rings corresponding to these lattice planes of (111), (220), (311), (400) and (311) can be observed in Fig. 3h. It also demonstrates that the PNSi has lower crystal degree. The result of crystal degree of PNSi is consistent with that of the XRD analysis (Fig. 2b).
The electrochemical performance of the core-shell AG@PNSi@C was
investigated by assembling coin-type half-cells and using discharge/charge cycling in a voltage range from 0.01 V to 1.5 V vs Li/Li+, the electrochemical properties of the PNSi, AG, AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes were studied as well, to analyze the function of the unique core-shell structure of AG@PNSi@C. Fig. 4a shows the discharge/charge profiles of the AG@PNSi@C and the PNSi electrode at a current density of 100 mAh g-1. The discharge/charge curves of the PNSi electrode shows a distinct discharge voltage plateau around 0.1 V, demonstrating that the lithium had embedded in the PNSi to form lithium silicon alloy. Some research results claimed that intercalation of lithium ion into silicon electrodes generates the formation of lithium silicon alloy, such as Li12Si7, Li14Si6, Li13Si4 and Li22Si5 [27, 48, 49]. The initial discharge/charge capacities of PNSi were 3521.6 and 2914.3 mAh g-1, respectively, and the initial Coulombic efficiency reached 82.7%. For the AG@PNSi@C electrode, the initial discharge/charge capacities are nearly 553 and 448 mAh g-1, respectively. The initial Coulombic efficiency was 81.0%. The lost
capacity is owing to the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) films on the surface of the PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrode, leading to the lower Coulombic efficiency [50, 51]. Although the formation of the SEI films consumes a few lithium ions forming inactive lithium, the SEI films cannot be dissolved in the organic electrolyte because it cannot react with the organic electrolytes. After the 1st cycle, the discharge capacities of AG@PNSi@C remain steady, i.e. 448.2 mAh g-1 of the 2nd cycle, 469.7 mAh g-1 of the 100th cycle, 500.5 mAh g-1 of the 200th cycle and 449.4 mAh g-1 of the 500th cycle. In contrast, the discharge capacity of PNSi dropped to 104.3 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles. The AG@PNSi@C electrode possesses a good stability due to the better conductivity of carbon materials (graphite and pitch carbon) and the volume cushion impact of the core-shell structure (Fig. 3b~g).
As shown in Fig. 4b, the cycling performance of the pure PNSi, AG, AG@PNSi
and AG@PNSi@C electrodes had been compared at a same current density of 100 mA g-1. The AG@PNSi@C electrode exhibits an excellent long cyclic property with a lower capacity fading in contrast to the pure PNSi and AG@PNSi electrodes. The pure PNSi electrode shows extremely poor cycling stability fading from 3521.6 mAh g-1 to 558.5 mAh g-1 after merely 30 cycles. For the AG@PNSi electrode, the discharge specific capacity decreases sharply from 531 to 407 mAh g-1 in the first 8 cycles and maintain at 346.9 mAh g-1 after 500 cycles. For instance, the discharge specific capacities of AG@PNSi@C electrode are 486.0 mAh g-1 and 449.4 mAh g-1 after 300 cycles and 500 cycles, respectively. The Coulombic efficiency of the
AG@PNSi@C electrode reaches 100%, except the first cycle. The results prove that the AG@PNSi@C possesses outstanding cycling stability, which is ascribed to graphite enhancing its conductivity and core-shell structure buffering the volume expansion.
The rate capabilities of PNSi, AG, AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes are
displayed in Fig. 4c. It is obvious that the rate capability of pure PNSi is very poor. Compared with the pure PNSi, the rate capability of the AG@PNSi electrode had a certain degree of improvement. The discharge capacity of the AG@PNSi electrode is approximately 73 mAh g-1 at current density of 1.2C (0.6 A g-1) and 43 mAh g-1 at current density of 2C (1.0 A g-1). The discharge capacity can recover to 380 mAh g-1 when the current density is set to 0.2C (0.1 A g-1) again. The AG@PNSi@C exhibits the best rate capability in contrast to PNSi, AG and AG@PNSi electrodes. When the current density was 1.2C (0.6 A g-1), the discharge capacity of the AG@PNSi@C is 322 mAh g-1 which is much higher than that of the AG@PNSi. The discharge capacity of the AG@PNSi@C is 272 mAh g-1 even at a current density of 2C (1.0 A g-1). In addition, the discharge capacity could recover to 485 mAh g-1 when the current density is changed back to 0.2C (0.1 A g-1). In summary, the AG@PNSi@C exhibits more excellent rate performance, compared with the PNSi and AG@PNSi. The excellent rate capability of AG@PNSi@C is owing to enhanced electronic conductivity of graphite, pitch carbon layer and improved structural stability of the core-shell architecture design (Fig. 3b~g).
Cyclic voltammetry (CV) characteristics of PNSi, AG, AG@PNSi and
AG@PNSi@C electrodes are conducted in a voltage range from 0.01 to 2.5 V at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s-1 in Fig. 5a~d. Fig. 5a shows CV curves of PNSi. The sharp cathodic peak at ~0 V was due to the lithiation of crystalline Si (c-Si + xLi → aLixSi). After the first cycle, the crystalline Si phases into amorphous Si owing to lithium insertion. In the later cycles, the two anodic peaks at 0.37 V and 0.53 V were ascribed to the low-potential delithiation (0.35 V, a-Lix+ySi →a-LixSi + yLi + ye -) and the high-potential delithiation (0.53 V, a-LixSi → a-Si + xLi + xe -) of the a-Li-Si alloy [52, 53]. In the first cycle (Fig. 5d), the two broad cathodic peaks at 0.95 V and 0.55 V are ascribed to the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) films on the surface of the AG@PNSi@C electrode [54, 55]. The anodic peak at 0.13 V shown up in the later cycles, corresponds to lithium insertion to form the amorphous LixSi phase (a-Si + xLi → a-LixSi) [39, 52, 56]. The anodic peak at 0.35 V is attributed to the extraction of Li-Si alloy. Compared with unmodified PNSi, CV curves of the AG@PNSi@C electrode exhibits a good overlap. Fig. 5a~d and Fig. 5e clearly present that the integral area of the CV curves of AG@PNSi@C electrode have a smaller change than that of pure PNSi and AG@PNSi electrodes, which indicates a stable cyclic performance for the AG@PNSi@C electrode.
Impedance spectra of PNSi, AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C fresh electrodes are
shown in Fig. 5f. The RS represents the resistance of the bull electrolyte [3]. The Nyquist plots of these spectra are composed of a depressed semi-circle in high
frequency region and an uphill line in low frequency region. The semi-circles are corresponding to the charge transfer resistance (RC) of the electrode [32]. The uphill lines deviating from 45° represent the solid phase diffusion impedances that the Li+ diffuses in the electrodes. A Warburg impedance (ZW) of 45° with typical of semiinfinite diffusion, is surveyed in general from micron dimension insertion materials (such as graphite). Nevertheless, nano-structure with 20~80 nm silicon particles can shrink the solid phase diffusion paths, meaning that the uphill lines will deviate from 45° in low frequency region [32]. In Fig. 5f and Tab. 1, the values of RS, RC and slope corresponding to these electrodes are exhibited clearly. It is clear that the PNSi electrode possesses the highest value (18 Ω) of the resistivity of the bull electrolyte (RS). However, the values (RS) of the AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes, 3.8 and 4.3 Ω, respectively, are smaller than the PNSi electrode’s. The charge transfer resistance (RC) of the PNSi, AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes descend in turn, which are 145, 105 and 99 Ω, respectively (Tab. 1) [32, 47]. It is obvious that the AG@PNSi@C electrode presents the lowest the value of RC, deducing that the AG@PNSi@C electrode is more advantageous in term of electronic conduction. In addition, the angles of the uphill lines in low frequency region, for the PNSi, AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes, are 53.2°, 55.5° and 69.1°, respectively. The angle of the AG@PNSi@C electrode is the maximum, which harmonized well with the corresponding electrochemical performance [32, 47, 57]. Fig. 5g displays the impedance spectra of (g) AG@PNSi@C electrode after 0th, 1st, 200th and 350th cycles at 100 mA g-1. After 1st cycle, two semicircles are apparently observed that the
first small one corresponds to SEI resistance (RSEI) and the second one corresponds to charge transfer resistance (RC) [58]. After cycling, the AG@PNSi@C electrode exhibits the small resistance increase. Above all, the results reveal that the the AG@PNSi@C presents the smallest impedance, in comparison to the PNSi and AG@PNSi electrodes, which is ascribed to the core-shell structure of the AG@PNSi@C presented in Fig. 3.
The surface morphology of the original electrode and after 500 cycles, for PNSi,
AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C, are displayed by SEM in Fig. 6. Fig. 6a~b show the surface morphology of the original PNSi electrode with varied magnifications. Compared with the PNSi electrode before cycling, the surface of the PNSi electrode after 500 cycles appeared lots of cracks owing to enormous volume expansion of PNSi during the discharge/charge processes, further resulting in collapse of electrode in Fig. 6a and 6c. Fig. 6b shows that PNSi particles before cycling distributed evenly and had no reunion. After 500 cycles, those PNSi particles fractured to form smaller particles and occurred serious reunion in Fig. 6d. As shown in Fig. 6e~l, although a few micro-cracks appeared on the surface of AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes after 500 cycles, their whole morphology maintained well without materials loss, which is due to the filling of graphite buffering the volume changes. Comparing the AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C particles of before cycling and after 500 cycles by examples, a small part of the particle on the surface of them broke off
in Fig. 6h and 6l, but the integrity of the structure for AG@PNSi@C was better than that of AG@PNSi because of the protection of pitch carbon layer. All in all, AG@PNSi@C composed of PNSi, AG and pitch carbon maintained the structural integrity after 500 cycles, corresponding to more stable cyclic performance than that of AG@PNSi and AG@PNSi@C electrodes (Fig. 4b). 4. Conclusions
To sum up, the carbon-coated AG@PNSi@C materials with core-shell structure
have been successfully synthesized by a facile and mass producible spray drying method. The AG@PNSi@C composite exhibits high initial Coulombic efficiency with 81.0%, long cycle life with the capacity of 449.4 mAh g-1 over 500 cycles and outstanding rate capability, the specific capacity can be recovered 485 mAh g-1 when the current density was set to 0.2C (0.1 A g-1) from 2C (1.0 A g-1). The excellent electrochemical performance is ascribed to its core-shell structure, in which that PNSi particles, wrapped in the pitch carbon layer, were evenly dispersed on the surface of graphite core. The research results indicate that the synthesized materials are promising anode for LIBs. By combining with graphite and pitch carbon, the Si-based electrode has been reported remarkable improvement in cycling stability. This kind of composites possess several advantages: (a) graphite not only can disperse the Si nanoparticles but also cushion huge volume changes during the charge and discharge process; (b) pitch carbon, as the shell of the AG@PNSi@C composite, separated the Si particles from the electrolyte and prevents Si from reacting with electrolyte; the carbon materials, such as graphite and pitch carbon, enhance the conductivity of Si-
based anode.

metadata.abstractText: Carbon-coated core-shell structure artificial graphite@plasma nanosilicon@carbon (AG@PNSi@C) composite, applying as lithium ion battery anode material, has been prepared via spray drying method. The plasma nano-silicon (˂ 100 nm), which contained amorphous silicon, was synthesized by radio frequency induction plasma system with the high temperatures processing capability and high quench rates. The artificial graphite in the composite acts as the core which supports the particle and provides electroconductivity, while PNSi attached on the surface of the core, enhances the specific capacity of the composite. The as prepared composite shows superior performance as anode in lithium-ion batteries, regarding to the initial Coulombic efficiency and cycle life. The initial Coulombic efficiency of AG@PNSi@C electrode is 81.0% with a discharge capacity of 553 mAh g and a recharge capacity of 448 mAh g. During cycling, AG@PNSi@C exhibits excellent performance with a very low capacity fading that the discharge capacity maintains 498.2 mAh g and 449.4 mAh g after 250 cycles and 500 cycles. AG@PNSi@C also shows enhanced resistance against high current density. Besides the remarkable electrochemical performances, the facile and mass-producible synthesis process makes the AG@PNSi@C composite very promising for its application in lithium-ion batteries.
